subtitle: This Chinese favourite is wonderfully tasty, as a main meal or a starter. Great for entertaining.

method.text: Pour boiling water over the duckling, turning over to evenly coat and seal the skin. Wipe duckling with kitchen towel to dry. Brush with honey until glazed all over.
Place the duck, breast side up, in a roasting tin on a wire rack. Roast in oven, without basting, for 15 min per 450 g, until the duck is tender and cooked through and the skin is dark and crispy.

Meanwhile, sift the flour into a bowl, pour in the cold water, stirring until well mixed. Turn out onto a lightly floured surface and knead until smooth. Cover bowl with a damp cloth and leave to stand for 30 min.

Divide dough into 4 equal portions. Shape into long sausage shapes and cut each into 9 small pieces. Shape each into a ball and flatten out to form a 15 cm circle. Brush the top and bottom of each pancake very lightly with a little sesame oil.

Heat a heavy-based non-greased frying pan over a medium heat until hot. Cook each pancake for 1-2 min, or until puffed up and light brown spots appear on the underside. Flip over and cook the other side. Remove from pan and stack on a plate, covering with a cloth until all are cooked. Then steam the pancakes over a pan of simmering water for 8-10 min, or until piping hot.

Meanwhile, carve duck by removing the legs and cutting the meat from the breast downwards. Cut the meat into small strips and serve on a warmed serving plate with the steamed pancakes, prepared vegetables and plum sauce.
To serve, simply spread the pancake with the sauce, top with a little shredded meat and vegetables and roll up.

title: Crispy Peking-style duck pancakes
